body:
Comment 7 by **emage@spamcop.net**: 
The difference is that the map implementation apparently reserves the right to assume
that its values are _simple_ -- that is, that they won't change once inserted unless
a new map-insert-operation happens and can thus be freely moved around in memory if
the map so desires.  A pointer has this property -- when you modify fields inside a
map[T1]*T2, it does not change the map value, only the pointed-to data.  When you
modify fields inside a map[T1]T2, it directly changes the contents of the value
"inside" the map, as I understand it.
